paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted genetic variant information for the TTR gene, including penetrance data.

patients.phenotype: familial amyloidotic polyneuropathy with cardiac involvement

individual_records.evidence_sentence: For instance, the p.Val122Ile pathogenic variant has been reported in African or Afro-Caribbean descent with an estimated population prevalence of 3% to 4%.

functional_data.summary: The p.Val122Ile variant is known to destabilize the TTR tetramer, leading to amyloid formation.

variants.segregation_data: The variant segregates with disease in families.
variants.population_frequency: Estimated population prevalence of 3% to 4% in specific ethnic groups.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on population studies.
variants.source_location: Main Text, paragraph discussing TTR variants.
variants.additional_notes: The variant is associated with both neurological and cardiac symptoms.
key_quotes: The median age at diagnosis ranges from 60–70 years-old, depending on the gene variant.
The inherited form is less prevalent than the ATTRwt.

patients.demographics: endemic in some areas of Portugal, Japan, Sweden, and Spain
patients.phenotype: early onset disease characterized by peripheral neuropathy and later cardiac involvement

individual_records.phenotype_details: peripheral neuropathy with later cardiac involvement
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Val30Met (p.Val50Met renamed according to the updated nomenclature) is the most common mutation worldwide.

functional_data.summary: The Val30Met variant is known to cause instability in the TTR protein, leading to amyloid formation.

variants.segregation_data: The variant is known to segregate with disease in families.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on population studies.
variants.source_location: Main Text, paragraph discussing TTR variants.
variants.additional_notes: This variant has a bimodal presentation.
key_quotes: This variant has a bimodal presentation with an early onset disease in the third-to-fourth decade of life characterized by peripheral neuropathy and a onset leading to cardiac involvement.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data for TTR variants were extracted successfully.
